item.title: Ukraine War: Counter-offensive troops punch through Russia line, generals claim
item.description: Kyiv says its troops are gaining momentum in what continues to be a lengthy and bloody counter-offensive.

item.title: One in five children regularly miss school, figures show
item.description: Parents should get their children back to school this week, the children's commissioner urges.

item.title: Labour reshuffle: Sir Keir Starmer to shake up shadow cabinet
item.description: There is much speculation over what role Sir Keir may give his deputy leader Angela Rayner.

item.title: Family courts: Mothers dying after 'abusers' claim access to children
item.description: One death came after family courts ordered a child to live with a paedophile, a BBC investigation finds.

item.title: Rail disruption: Train cancellations as high as 13% in 2023
item.description: One station, managed by TransPennine Express, has had 13% of its trains cancelled.

item.title: Torrential rain in Spain causes major flooding
item.description: Atletico Madrid and Seville's football match was called off as a red alert was issued in the capital.

item.title: Ukraine's defence minister Oleksii Reznikov dismissed
item.description: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky dismissed Oleksii Reznikov, saying "new approaches" were needed.

item.title: Children's futures at risk as more put to work - UN
item.description: The head of the UN agency says the world needs to act fast to get children out of exploitative work.

item.title: Boy thrown from Tate Modern using wheelchair a lot less, family says
item.description: The child survived a 100ft (30m) fall in 2019 but suffered life-changing injuries.

item.title: Jeremy Hunt says government will 'spend what it takes' to make schools safe
item.description: Labour calls the chancellor's funding promise a "bare bones" response to the crumbly concrete crisis.

item.title: Paul McCartney: Global search for missing Beatles' 1961 Höfner guitar
item.description: Paul McCartney changed music history playing iconic Höfner guitar - but it hasn't been seen since 1969.

item.title: Minnesota jail in lockdown as 100 inmates refuse to return to cells
item.description: Prisoners are reportedly protesting conditions at the facility amid hot conditions.

item.title: US Open 2023 results: Coco Gauff ends Caroline Wozniacki's comeback run
item.description: Coco Gauff shows why she is one the favourites at the US Open with a gutsy win over Caroline Wozniacki to reach the quarter-finals.

item.title: The Papers: 'No cash for school repairs' and Labour tax pledge
item.description: The issue of crumbling concrete is on the front of some of Monday's papers.

item.title: Teacher suicide exposes parent bullying in S Korea
item.description: Tens of thousands of primary school teachers have gone on strike demanding better protection at work.

item.title: Gail Porter on comedy: 'Has anyone here been sectioned?'
item.description: The TV star on being sectioned, getting into comedy and balancing her finances.

item.title: New tech boosts Dutch drive for sustainable farming
item.description: In the Netherlands, experiments are underway to ensure future food supply and cut carbon emissions.

item.title: Lagos traffic jams disappear. But this isn't good news for Nigeria
item.description: The removal of a fuel subsidy has pushed the cost of transport out of the reach of many Nigerians.

item.title: Threats, insults, and Kremlin 'robots': How Russian diplomacy died under Putin
item.description: Russian diplomacy is no longer about co-operation but "putting Westerners in their place", say ex-Kremlin insiders.

item.title: Why your burger may not always look like the advert
item.description: Burger King is facing a US lawsuit over images of its Whoppers, but advertisers are allowed to exaggerate.

item.title: Berliners rave against motorway extension threatening cultural venues
item.description: Clubbers hold street party protesting against plan to flatten 20 venues in path of ring road extension

item.title: Johannesburg fire: Hijacks and death traps in a crumbling South African city centre
item.description: Criminal gangs 'hijack' buildings in South Africa, and then they burn down. And no-one seems able to stop them.

item.title: Nats air traffic control fault: Experts reflect on three days of chaos
item.description: Why did a fault that was fixed promptly delay so many flights?

item.title: Mitch McConnell: After health scare, voters weigh in on whether politicians are too old
item.description: The 81-year-old Republican appeared to freeze for the second time in just over a month while speaking to reporters.

item.title: Fukushima: China's anger at Japan is fuelled by disinformation
item.description: Scientists have backed Japan's treated waste water release, but Beijing's protest remains loud.

item.title: Burning Man: Police investigating death during heavy rain
item.description: Thousands of people remain stuck at the event in Nevada and could remain so for several more days.

item.title: Sunak joins King Charles and Queen Camilla at Balmoral Sunday service
item.description: The prime minister and his wife Akshata Murthy joined the Royal Family at their Balmoral estate.

item.title: Crystal Palace: Man arrested after alleged racist abuse of Wolves player during match
item.description: A man in his 60s is arrested after allegedly racially abusing a Wolves player at Crystal Palace's Selhurst Park during Sunday's Premier League game.

item.title: South Africa says inquiry finds no evidence of arms shipment to Russia
item.description: A national inquiry rejects US claims a Russian cargo ship was uploaded with South African weapons.

item.title: Manchester United: Jadon Sancho says he is 'a scapegoat' after being dropped
item.description: Jadon Sancho says he is "a scapegoat" after Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag said he was dropped for Sunday's loss to Arsenal because of poor training performance.

item.title: I've never told anyone to hack a phone - Piers Morgan
item.description: The former editor of the Daily Mirror denies ever hacking phones or telling anyone to do so while he was at the newspaper.

item.title: Coventry: Pedestrian and cyclist hit by car die from injuries
item.description: A man is being questioned after three people were hurt, two fatally, in separate collisions.

item.title: Mo Farah finishes fourth in The Big Half in final London race
item.description: Mo Farah's final race in his home city of London ends with a fourth-placed finish in The Big Half, as Jack Rowe wins.

item.title: Australia launches mission to rescue Antarctic researcher
item.description: An icebreaker is sent from Tasmania to evacuate an Australian with a "developing medical condition".

item.title: Declan Rice: The game-changing midfielder Arsenal need for title challenge
item.description: Big players deliver the big moments to decide the big games and Arsenal's Declan Rice did that on every level against Manchester United, writes Phil McNulty.

item.title: England v New Zealand: Finn Allen hits 83 as tourists win third T20 by 74 runs
item.description: England are outplayed by a resurgent New Zealand who clinch the third T20 international by 74 runs at Edgbaston.

item.title: MOTD2 analysis: How Trent Alexander-Arnold gave a "passing masterclass"
item.description: Match of the Day 2's Mark Chapman, Jermaine Jenas and Stephen Warnock discuss how Liverpool's Trent Alexander-Arnold delivered a "passing masterclass".

item.title: Garth Crooks' Team of the Week: Pickford, Szoboszlai, Haaland, Ferguson, Son and more
item.description: Which players impressed our football pundit Garth Crooks enough to make his latest Team of the Week?

item.title: Mohamed Salah: Jurgen Klopp 'has no doubt' over forward's commitment to Liverpool
item.description: Liverpool could be bracing themselves for more bids for Mohamed Salah this week but Jurgen Klopp is "calm despite the fuss" about the forward's future.

item.title: Rangers 0-1 Celtic: Kyogo Furuhashi sign of champions' strength at Ibrox
item.description: BBC Sport Scotland chief sportswriter Tom English analyses Celtic's win in the first Scottish Premiership Old Firm game of the season.

item.title: List of schools that have closed, shut buildings or moved over RAAC concrete
item.description: The government is not publishing a list of which schools are affected, but this is what we know.

item.title: Ros Atkins on... questions for government over RAAC
item.description: The BBC's Analysis Editor takes a look at four questions the government is being asked about potentially dangerous concrete in schools in England.

item.title: School closures: BBC correspondent explains why this concrete is dangerous
item.description: BBC Home Affairs Correspondent Tom Symonds explains why RAAC is more dangerous than standard concrete.

item.title: What is RAAC concrete and where is it in schools and hospitals?
item.description: Questions mount about aerated concrete used in schools and public buildings since the 1950s.

item.title: How will I know if my child's school is closed? Your questions answered
item.description: Will more schools need to close? Why is this happening? Our experts on what you need to know.

item.title: Parents tell of shock as scale of school closures emerges
item.description: Concrete safety fears have thrown the new term into turmoil at more than 100 schools in England.

item.title: RAAC: Public buildings at risk from concrete failure, experts warn
item.description: Specialists say RAAC concrete was widely used in public buildings in the UK.

item.title: Essex: 50 schools fitted with crumbling concrete, says council
item.description: Parents and children speak of "heartbreak" at hearing their school buildings are closing.

item.title: 35 council-run schools in Scotland found to contain RAAC
item.description: A total of 35 council-run schools have been found to contain RAAC, the Scottish government confirms.

item.title: RAAC ‘is like a concrete Aero bar’
item.description: An architect explains the issues around RAAC which has caused closures of schools.

item.title: Faulty concrete likely in Wales, says building expert
item.description: Weaker concrete is probably in schools and other buildings in Wales, says leading civil engineer.

item.title: NI schools urgently checked over concrete concerns
item.description: It is not yet known how long it will take to check for collapse-prone concrete in NI schools.

item.title: What you need to know about school concrete scare
item.description: BBC reporter Vanessa Clarke explains a bit more about schools affected by closures over safety fears.

item.title: What are my rights if my flight is cancelled or delayed?
item.description: Technical glitches have caused disruption at airports but passengers do have rights.

item.title: Five ways to save money on your packed lunch
item.description: The lunchbox is back after the summer holidays so here are some top tips on making savings at lunchtime.

item.title: How to get a job: Six expert tips for finding work
item.description: There are 10m people out of work in the UK, so if you're searching for a job you're not alone. Here are some tips on how to get started.

item.title: Food prices: How can I save money on my grocery shop?
item.description: The cost-of-living crisis continues to bite. Here are some things that can reduce the impact.

item.title: What is happening to house prices, and could there be a crash?
item.description: How higher interest rates are changing the UK's housing market.

item.title: Energy bills: What can I do if I can't afford to pay?
item.description: If you're struggling to afford your gas and electricity bills, what options are available?

item.title: Interest rate and mortgages: What you can do about rising payments
item.description: Watch the BBC's Lora Jones tell you five things you can do about your mortgage, in a minute.

item.title: Train strikes: When is the next action happening?
item.description: Members of the RMT rail workers' union and Aslef train drivers' union are set to strike again.

item.title: First time home buyers: How much can I borrow?
item.description: With rents rising, more people are crunching the numbers to see if they can afford to buy.

item.title: Fuel cost: How to save petrol and diesel
item.description: With weak competition adding to fuel prices, are drivers doing the right things to save money?

item.title: Rent increases: What you can do about a rise from your landlord
item.description: The BBC's Lora Jones tells you four things you can do, if your landlord asks for more money.

item.title: Cost-of-living payments: Who is getting them and when?
item.description: Low-income households, pensioners and some disabled people will get extra help with energy bills.

item.title: Mortgage rates: Five ways to save money
item.description: Experts give advice for those who might be worried about their monthly mortgage payments.

item.title: Renting: What are your rights as a tenant?
item.description: With one in five people now renting in the UK, it's important to understand your rights as a tenant.

item.title: Renting: Three ways to win the race to securing a property
item.description: From being first in the queue to being more flexible, here are some tips on how to get ahead in the rental race.

item.title: Rent prices: How much have they gone up in your area?
item.description: Use our interactive tool to find out what the average rent is in your area.

item.title: Why inflation is falling but prices are still rising
item.description: We report this percentage every month but here are three things you may not know.

item.title: UK inflation rate calculator: How much are prices rising for you?
item.description: Use our calculator to find out how much the cost of living is going up in your household.

item.title: Debt: What do I do if I can't afford to pay?
item.description: What help and options are available to people struggling with debt repayments?
